pages.home: EthioDirect ‚Äî Coffee That Was Waiting for You
pages.blog_subtitle: Dive into the world of specialty coffee: from Ethiopian plantations to your cup

sidamo_guide.title: Sidamo: Region of Berry Coffee
sidamo_guide.subtitle: Everything about the Sidamo coffee region
sidamo_guide.intro: Sidamo is one of Ethiopia's most famous coffee regions, known for its berry and citrus notes.
sidamo_guide.geography_p1: Sidamo (or Sidama) is a region in the Rift Valley in southern Ethiopia. Interestingly, Yirgacheffe is technically part of Sidamo but has gained its own status due to its unique flavor.
sidamo_guide.taste_value: milk chocolate, almond, soft citrus acidity
sidamo_guide.why_universal_desc: ‚Äî suitable for both espresso and filter
sidamo_guide.why_balance_desc: ‚Äî not too acidic, not too bitter
sidamo_guide.how_brew_intro: Sidamo is one of the most versatile coffees. It works great with:
sidamo_guide.brew_espresso_desc: ‚Äî medium roast, bright crema, chocolate flavor
sidamo_guide.our_sidamo_text: We work with cooperatives in the Bensa area ‚Äî one of the best sub-regions of Sidamo. Our coffee undergoes washed processing and has a score of 85 SCA points.
sidamo_guide.cta_text: Order authentic coffee from the Sidamo region
sidamo_guide.p_region: Sidamo is located in southern Ethiopia, at 1500-2200 meters elevation. The region has an ideal climate for growing Arabica: sufficient rainfall, moderate temperatures, and fertile soils.
sidamo_guide.p_taste: Sidamo coffee is known for its balanced taste with notes of berries, chocolate, and spices. Acidity ranges from moderate to bright, body is medium.

yirgacheffe_region.title: Yirgacheffe: Floral Paradise
yirgacheffe_region.subtitle: The unique terroir of Yirgacheffe region
yirgacheffe_region.intro: Yirgacheffe is considered Ethiopia's most prestigious coffee region. Coffee from here has bright floral notes, citrus acidity, and tea-like texture.
yirgacheffe_region.geography_p1: Yirgacheffe is a small district within the Sidamo region in southern Ethiopia. Thanks to its unique microclimate and ideal altitude (1750-2200 m), coffee here acquires a special character.

ethiopia_coffee_origin.title: Ethiopia ‚Äî The Birthplace of Coffee
ethiopia_coffee_origin.subtitle: History, legends and uniqueness
ethiopia_coffee_origin.intro: Ethiopia is the only country where coffee grows naturally in the wild. It was here that coffee was discovered over 1000 years ago thanks to the legendary shepherd Kaldi.
ethiopia_coffee_origin.legend_p1: According to legend, the shepherd Kaldi noticed that his goats became energetic after eating red berries from a certain bush. He told the monks about it, and thus began the history of coffee.
ethiopia_coffee_origin.cta_text: From the birthplace of coffee ‚Äî to your cup

what_is_specialty.title: What is Specialty Coffee and Why Does It Cost More
what_is_specialty.subtitle: Understanding what makes specialty coffee different, how professionals grade it, and why it's worth every penny.
what_is_specialty.intro: If you've ever wondered why one bag of coffee costs $5 while another costs $30, the answer lies in the concept of specialty coffee. This isn't just a marketing term ‚Äî behind it stands a strict grading system, decades of experience, and a true passion for quality.
what_is_specialty.definition: Specialty coffee is coffee that has scored 80 points or higher on the SCA 100-point scale.
what_is_specialty.quote1: "Specialty coffee represents about 3% of all coffee produced in the world. It's like comparing table wine with Grand Cru."
what_is_specialty.grading_intro: Coffee grading is a real science. Certified Q-graders analyze beans across 11 criteria.
what_is_specialty.why_expensive_title: Why is Specialty Coffee More Expensive?
what_is_specialty.recognize_title: How to Recognize Real Specialty Coffee
what_is_specialty.cta_title: Ready to Try Real Specialty Coffee?
what_is_specialty.cta_text: Browse our collection of Ethiopian coffee 85+ SCA
what_is_specialty.p_history: The term "specialty coffee" officially appeared in 1974 when Erna Knutsen, one of the coffee industry pioneers, first used it to describe the highest quality coffee. Since then, the concept has evolved and now has a clear definition.
what_is_specialty.p_definition: Specialty coffee is coffee that has scored 80 points or higher on the Specialty Coffee Association (SCA) 100-point scale. For comparison: regular commercial coffee rarely exceeds 70 points, and anything below 60 is considered low quality.
what_is_specialty.p_grading_intro: Coffee grading is a true science. Certified Q-graders (coffee experts) analyze beans using 11 criteria:
what_is_specialty.criteria_aroma: Aroma ‚Äî smell of dry and wet beans
what_is_specialty.p_grading_note: Each criterion is scored from 6 to 10 points. To achieve specialty status, beans must have no more than 5 defects per 350 grams upon visual inspection.
what_is_specialty.h2_why_expensive: Why is Specialty Coffee More Expensive?
what_is_specialty.p_expensive_intro: The high price of specialty coffee isn't a marketing markup. Real costs exist at every stage:
what_is_specialty.p_terroir: The best coffee grows at 1800-2200 meters above sea level, in a tropical climate with distinct seasons. These conditions exist only in a few regions of the world, and Ethiopia is one of them.
what_is_specialty.p_harvest: Unlike commercial coffee that's often machine-harvested, specialty cherries are hand-picked, selecting only ripe ones. It's 10 times slower but guarantees quality.
what_is_specialty.p_processing: Every step ‚Äî from fermentation to drying ‚Äî is manually controlled. Natural processing can take up to 4 weeks.
what_is_specialty.p_roasting: Specialty coffee has optimal taste within 2-4 weeks after roasting. At EthioDirect, we roast to order.
what_is_specialty.p_fairtrade: Farmers receive fair prices ‚Äî often 2-3 times higher than market rates.
what_is_specialty.h2_recognize: How to Recognize Real Specialty Coffee
what_is_specialty.tip_date: Roast Date ‚Äî should be printed, not "best before"
what_is_specialty.tip_origin: Origin ‚Äî region specified, even better ‚Äî farm name
what_is_specialty.tip_sca: SCA Score ‚Äî if 80+ points are indicated, it's a good sign
what_is_specialty.tip_volume: Small Volume ‚Äî specialty is rarely sold in 1kg packages
what_is_specialty.p_worth_intro: If coffee is a pleasure, ritual, and moment of enjoyment for you ‚Äî absolutely yes.
what_is_specialty.p_worth_flavors: Specialty coffee will open a world of flavors you never suspected: from floral jasmine notes to berry sweetness of blueberry, from citrus freshness to chocolate depth. It's an entirely different experience.
what_is_specialty.quote2: "When I first tried real Ethiopian Yirgacheffe, I realized that until then I hadn't been drinking coffee ‚Äî just bitter caffeinated liquid."
what_is_specialty.p_conclusion: Try it at least once ‚Äî and you'll understand what we're talking about. And our 85+ point coffee is a perfect start to this journey.
what_is_specialty.li_aroma: Aroma ‚Äî the smell of dry and wet grounds
what_is_specialty.li_aftertaste: Aftertaste ‚Äî duration and quality of taste
what_is_specialty.li_body: Body ‚Äî the density of the drink
what_is_specialty.li_sweetness: Sweetness ‚Äî natural sweetness of the bean
what_is_specialty.li_small_batch: Small batch ‚Äî specialty rarely sold in large packages

light_vs_dark_roast.title: Light vs Dark Roast
light_vs_dark_roast.subtitle: How roast level affects taste
light_vs_dark_roast.intro: Roasting is the key stage that determines the character of coffee. Light roast reveals terroir and acidity, dark adds body and bitterness.
light_vs_dark_roast.light_desc: Preserves the original bean flavor, emphasizes fruity and floral notes. Ideal for Specialty coffee.
light_vs_dark_roast.dark_desc: Adds caramel, chocolate notes. Less acidity, more bitterness. Classic for espresso.

water_for_coffee.title: Water for Coffee: Complete Guide
water_for_coffee.subtitle: How water affects your coffee taste
water_for_coffee.intro: Coffee is 98% water, so water quality is critical. Too soft water gives flat taste, too hard ‚Äî too bitter.
water_for_coffee.p_why: Water is the solvent that extracts flavor compounds from coffee. Too soft water gives weak extraction, too hard ‚Äî excessive bitterness.
water_for_coffee.p_ideal: Per SCA recommendations: TDS (total dissolved solids) 75-250 ppm, pH 6.5-7.5. Simplest option ‚Äî filtered water or quality bottled water.
water_for_coffee.p_avoid: Distilled water ‚Äî too soft. Tap water (in most cities) ‚Äî contains chlorine and is too hard. High-mineral water ‚Äî will overpower coffee taste.

yirgacheffe.title: Yirgacheffe: The Gem of Ethiopian Coffee
yirgacheffe.subtitle: Why this region produces one of the world's most expensive coffees and what flavors to look for.
yirgacheffe.intro: Yirgacheffe (pronounced "Yeer-ga-chef-eh") is a legendary region in southern Ethiopia that produces one of the world's most recognizable coffees.
yirgacheffe.location_text: Yirgacheffe is a small town and surrounding region in the Gedeo zone, in the Sidamo region (SNNPR) of southern Ethiopia. Altitude ‚Äî 1700-2200 meters above sea level, creating ideal conditions for slow berry ripening.
yirgacheffe.terroir_text: Volcanic soils rich in minerals, even climate with rainy seasons, high altitude ‚Äî all this creates a unique "terroir", similar to famous wine regions.
yirgacheffe.genetics_text: A unique subspecies of Arabica grows here ‚Äî Ethiopian Heirloom. This is not a cultivated variety, but wild varieties that have been preserved for millennia.
yirgacheffe.processing_text: Most Yirgacheffe coffee is processed using the washed method, which emphasizes its clarity and floral notes. Naturally processed is rarer but has an even more intense berry flavor.
yirgacheffe.quote: "Yirgacheffe is not just coffee. It's perfume in a cup. Close your eyes ‚Äî and you're in a flower garden."
yirgacheffe.roast_value: only light or very light medium
yirgacheffe.not_rec_value: Turkish or espresso ‚Äî will overshadow delicate notes
yirgacheffe.our_text: We work directly with a cooperative in the Kochere region (one of the best micro-regions of Yirgacheffe). Our coffee has a score of 88 SCA points and a bright profile: jasmine, bergamot, lemon zest.
yirgacheffe.p_geography: The region is located at 1700-2200 meters above sea level, in the Gedeo zone. These are ideal conditions for Arabica: cool nights, moderate days, adequate rainfall, and rich volcanic soils.
yirgacheffe.p_taste: Yirgacheffe is famous for its unique taste: bright floral notes (jasmine, bergamot), citrus acidity (lemon, orange), tea-like body, and a long sweet aftertaste.
yirgacheffe.p_processing: Traditionally, Yirgacheffe is washed, giving a clean, bright taste. But lately, natural processing is becoming more popular ‚Äî it adds sweetness and berry notes.

ethiopia_origin.title: Ethiopia ‚Äî The Birthplace of Coffee
ethiopia_origin.subtitle: Learn about the history and uniqueness of Ethiopian coffee
ethiopia_origin.intro: Ethiopia is the only country in the world where coffee grows wild. It was here, over 1000 years ago, that shepherd Kaldi first noticed his goats becoming more energetic after eating red berries.
ethiopia_origin.legend_p1: In the 9th century, goatherd Kaldi noticed: his goats, after eating red berries from an unknown bush, became extremely energetic ‚Äî jumping and unable to sleep.
ethiopia_origin.quote1: "The goats danced in the moonlight. Kaldi understood ‚Äî these berries have magical power."
ethiopia_origin.legend_p2: Kaldi tried the berries himself and felt a surge of energy. He took them to a monastery, where the monks first threw them into the fire. But the incredible aroma of the roasted beans made them reconsider ‚Äî thus the first coffee drink was born.
ethiopia_origin.century16_text: ‚Äî became popular in the Ottoman Empire
ethiopia_origin.century18_text: ‚Äî spread to colonies and became a global commodity
ethiopia_origin.diversity_text: over 10,000 Arabica varieties ‚Äî more than all other countries combined.
ethiopia_origin.traditions_text: most coffee is grown in the shade of natural forest, without chemicals.
ethiopia_origin.quote2: "In Ethiopia they say: 'Buna dabo naw' ‚Äî 'Coffee is our bread'."
ethiopia_origin.h2_legend: The Legend of Kaldi the Goatherd
ethiopia_origin.p_legend1: The most famous legend about coffee's origin tells of an Ethiopian goatherd named Kaldi, who lived around the 9th century AD.
ethiopia_origin.p_legend2: One day, Kaldi noticed that his goats became extraordinarily energetic and active after eating red berries from an unknown bush. They jumped, ran, and couldn't calm down until late at night.
ethiopia_origin.p_legend3: The curious shepherd decided to try the berries himself. Feeling a surge of energy, he brought his discovery to the local monastery.
ethiopia_origin.p_monastery1: The monks were initially skeptical of the discovery. According to one version, the abbot even threw the berries into the fire, calling them "the devil's work."
ethiopia_origin.p_monastery2: But when the berries began to roast, the room filled with an incredible aroma. The monks retrieved the roasted beans, ground them, and poured hot water over them ‚Äî thus was born the first coffee drink.
ethiopia_origin.p_monastery3: The monks quickly appreciated the practical benefit: the drink helped them stay awake during long night prayers.
ethiopia_origin.p_spread1: Over the following centuries, coffee spread first to the Arabian Peninsula, then to Turkey, Venice, and the rest of Europe.
ethiopia_origin.p_spread2: But Ethiopia remains unique ‚Äî it's the only country in the world where coffee grows wild. Here you can find thousands of varieties that exist nowhere else.
ethiopia_origin.p_today1: Ethiopia is the fifth-largest coffee producer in the world and first in Africa. Coffee provides about 60% of the country's export revenue.
ethiopia_origin.p_today2: The most famous production regions: Yirgacheffe, Sidamo, Guji, Harrar, Limu. Each has a unique terroir and flavor profile.
ethiopia_origin.p_ceremony: In Ethiopia, coffee is more than a drink. The traditional coffee ceremony ("Buna") can last for hours and is an important part of social life. Beans are roasted, ground, and brewed right before guests.
ethiopia_origin.cta_text: Order authentic Ethiopian coffee from Yirgacheffe and Sidamo regions

light_vs_dark.title: Light vs Dark Roast: What to Choose?
light_vs_dark.subtitle: Understanding the difference between light and dark roasts
light_vs_dark.intro: Roasting is one of the most important factors affecting coffee taste. Light roast preserves the bean's natural characteristics, while dark roast creates a richer, caramel flavor.
light_vs_dark.process_text: Roasting is the thermal processing of green beans at 180-230¬∞C.
light_vs_dark.caffeine_myth_text: Many believe that dark roast is "stronger" and contains more caffeine. This is actually a myth!
light_vs_dark.cta_text: Our catalog has coffee from light to dark roast
light_vs_dark.p_process: Roasting is the thermal processing of green coffee beans at 180-230¬∞C. During this process, the bean undergoes chemical reactions that form the taste, aroma, and color of coffee.
light_vs_dark.p_light: The bean is roasted until the first "crack" ‚Äî a characteristic sound when the bean cracks from internal pressure. Color ‚Äî light brown.
light_vs_dark.p_medium: Roasting continues slightly longer after the first crack. Color ‚Äî rich brown. This is the most popular choice for most consumers.
light_vs_dark.p_dark: Roasting continues until the second crack and beyond. Color ‚Äî dark brown to almost black, often with an oily surface.
light_vs_dark.p_caffeine: Many believe that dark roast is "stronger" and contains more caffeine. Actually, this is a myth! The caffeine content is almost the same across all roasts, and sometimes light roast even contains slightly more.
light_vs_dark.p_choose: For alternative methods (V60, Aeropress) light roast works better. For espresso ‚Äî medium or dark. For Turkish coffee ‚Äî dark. But most importantly ‚Äî experiment!

natural_vs_washed.title: Natural vs Washed: How Processing Affects Taste
natural_vs_washed.subtitle: The difference between dry and washed processing and why it matters for your cup.
natural_vs_washed.intro: Processing is one of the key factors determining your coffee's taste. Let's explore how the two main methods differ.
natural_vs_washed.natural_text: Cherries are dried whole under the sun for 2-4 weeks. The pulp ferments and imparts sweetness to the bean.
natural_vs_washed.washed_text: Pulp is removed immediately, beans ferment in water. Clean, bright taste.
natural_vs_washed.honey_text: Partial pulp removal. Balance between natural and washed.
natural_vs_washed.p_washed: In washed processing, the fruit pulp is removed immediately after harvesting. The bean undergoes fermentation in water, then is washed and dried. Result: clean, bright taste with clear acidity.
natural_vs_washed.p_natural: In natural processing, the cherry dries whole ‚Äî with the pulp. The process takes 2-4 weeks. Result: rich, sweet taste with fruity and berry notes.
natural_vs_washed.p_difference: Washed coffee is more "clean" with clear notes. Natural is more "wild" with deep fruity flavors. Both methods have their fans.

grinder_guide.title: Coffee Grinder: How to Choose?
grinder_guide.subtitle: Burr vs Blade: complete comparison
grinder_guide.intro: A grinder is the most important tool after coffee itself. Proper grinding can completely change your drink's taste.
grinder_guide.p_blade: Blade grinders ‚Äî cheapest, but give uneven grind. Not recommended for specialty coffee.
grinder_guide.p_burr: Burr grinders ‚Äî come in flat and conical. Give even grind needed for proper extraction.
grinder_guide.p_manual: Manual ‚Äî cheaper, quiet, compact. Downside: need to crank 1-2 minutes. Electric ‚Äî fast and convenient, but more expensive.
grinder_guide.p_recommend: To start: manual Timemore C2 or Hario Skerton. For espresso: Baratza Encore or 1Zpresso JX-Pro.
grinder_guide.h2_1: Why Do You Need a Grinder?

aeropress_recipes.title: 3 Aeropress Recipes from Champions
aeropress_recipes.subtitle: Proven recipes from championship winners for the perfect cup at home.
aeropress_recipes.intro: Aeropress is one of the most versatile brewing methods. Here are three recipes from world championship winners.
aeropress_recipes.p_classic: 15g coffee, 200ml water 85¬∞C. Medium grind. Time: 1:30. Pour, stir, press.
aeropress_recipes.p_inverted: Aeropress inverted. 17g coffee, 220ml water 92¬∞C. Steep 2 minutes, flip, press.
aeropress_recipes.p_champion: 12g coffee, 200ml water 78¬∞C. Very fine grind. Time: 2:00. Result: rich, sweet taste.

cold_brew_recipe.title: Cold Brew at Home: Simple Recipe for 5 Liters
cold_brew_recipe.subtitle: How to make refreshing cold-brewed coffee without special equipment.
cold_brew_recipe.intro: Cold brew is the perfect drink for hot days. It's smooth, sweet, and almost bitter-free. Best of all ‚Äî it's easy to make at home.
cold_brew_recipe.p_what: Cold brew is coffee brewed with cold water for 12-24 hours. Unlike iced coffee (hot coffee with ice), cold brew is never heated.
cold_brew_recipe.p_ratio: Ratio: 1:8 (100g coffee to 800ml water). Coarse grind, like for French press.
cold_brew_recipe.p_steps: Mix coffee with cold water in a jar. Leave in fridge for 12-24 hours. Strain through filter. Concentrate can be diluted with water/milk 1:1.
cold_brew_recipe.p_tips: Use coffees with fruity notes ‚Äî they shine in cold brew. Store concentrate up to 2 weeks in fridge.

espresso_mistakes.title: 7 Espresso Making Mistakes
espresso_mistakes.subtitle: How to avoid common home barista mistakes
espresso_mistakes.intro: Even with an expensive machine, you can make bad coffee. Here are 7 most common mistakes beginners make.
espresso_mistakes.p_grind: Too coarse ‚Äî watery, sour shot. Too fine ‚Äî bitter, slow. Experiment!
espresso_mistakes.p_dose: Use scales! Standard dose ‚Äî 18-20g coffee for a double shot.
espresso_mistakes.p_temp: Ideal: 92-96¬∞C. Warm up the machine at least 15 minutes before first shot.
espresso_mistakes.p_fresh: Espresso is best from coffee 7-21 days after roasting. Fresh roast produces too much gas.
espresso_mistakes.p_tamp: Tamp evenly with ~15 kg pressure. Uneven tamping = uneven extraction.
espresso_mistakes.p_clean: Clean the group after every shot. Old oils = bitter taste.

turka_recipe.title: Turkish Coffee: Classic Recipe
turka_recipe.subtitle: Traditional brewing method in cezve
turka_recipe.intro: Turkish coffee is one of the oldest brewing methods. The secret to a perfect cup is in the details.
turka_recipe.p_equipment: Cezve (copper is best), very finely ground coffee, cold water, sand or low heat.
turka_recipe.p_step1: 7g coffee per 60ml cold water. Grind ‚Äî powder-fine, finer than espresso.
turka_recipe.p_step2: Mix coffee with cold water in cezve. Add sugar if desired.
turka_recipe.p_step3: Heat slowly on lowest flame. Never boil!
turka_recipe.p_step4: When foam starts to rise ‚Äî remove from heat. Repeat 2-3 times for richness.
turka_recipe.p_tips: Don't stir after heating starts. Use dark roast. Serve with a glass of cold water.

how_to_brew_v60.title: Perfect V60: Step-by-Step Recipe from a Barista
how_to_brew_v60.subtitle: Detailed instructions for brewing coffee with pour-over. Ratios, temperature, pouring technique.
how_to_brew_v60.intro: V60 is one of the most popular filter coffee brewing methods. Here's a step-by-step recipe used by professional baristas.
how_to_brew_v60.p_equipment: V60 dripper, paper filters, coffee grinder, gooseneck kettle, scale, timer, 15g coffee, 250ml water (94¬∞C).
how_to_brew_v60.p_ratio: Classic V60 ratio: 1:16.6 (15g coffee to 250ml water). For stronger coffee use 1:15, for lighter ‚Äî 1:17.
how_to_brew_v60.p_step1: Rinse the filter with hot water. This removes paper taste and preheats the dripper.
how_to_brew_v60.p_step2: Add ground coffee (medium-fine, like sea salt) and make a well in the center.
how_to_brew_v60.p_step3: Start with pre-infusion: pour 30ml water, wait 30-45 seconds while coffee "blooms."
how_to_brew_v60.p_step4: Continue pouring water in circles, from center to edges. Total brew time: 2:30-3:00.
how_to_brew_v60.cta_text: We recommend light roast for the best flavor

coffee_storage.title: How to Store Coffee Properly
coffee_storage.subtitle: Keep your coffee fresh as long as possible
coffee_storage.intro: Coffee is a product that quickly loses freshness. Here are the best storage practices.
coffee_storage.p_tips: Keep coffee in airtight packaging, in a dark cool place. Not in the fridge! Ground coffee keeps 2 weeks, beans ‚Äî up to a month after roasting.
coffee_storage.cta_text: We roast to order ‚Äî you'll receive the freshest coffee
coffee_storage.h2_4: Can You Store in the Fridge?

caffeine_myths.title: 5 Caffeine Myths
caffeine_myths.subtitle: Debunking popular myths about coffee and caffeine
caffeine_myths.intro: Many legends surround caffeine. Let's figure out what's true and what's not.
caffeine_myths.p_myth1: FALSE. Caffeine content is almost the same across all roasts. "Strength" refers to flavor, not caffeine.
caffeine_myths.h2_myth2: Myth 2: Espresso Has the Most Caffeine
caffeine_myths.p_myth2: PARTLY TRUE. Per milliliter ‚Äî yes. But a cup of filter coffee has more caffeine overall due to larger volume.
caffeine_myths.p_myth3: FALSE. Coffee is 98% water and is a mild diuretic. It doesn't dehydrate with normal consumption.
caffeine_myths.p_myth4: PARTLY TRUE. Tolerance develops, but it's not addiction in the medical sense. Withdrawal is mild discomfort for 1-2 days.
caffeine_myths.p_myth5: FALSE. Decaf contains 2-15 mg caffeine per cup (regular has 80-100 mg).
caffeine_myths.h3_2: Myth 2: Espresso Has the Most Caffeine

aeropress.title: AeroPress: 5 Best Recipes
aeropress.subtitle: From classic to championship recipes
aeropress.intro: AeroPress is a unique device that allows brewing coffee in countless ways. Here are 5 proven recipes for different flavor profiles.

v60_guide.title: V60: The Art of Pour Over
v60_guide.subtitle: Complete guide to brewing with Hario V60
v60_guide.intro: V60 by Hario is one of the most popular alternative brewing methods in the world. Its conical shape and spiral ribs allow unprecedented extraction control.

cold_brew.title: Cold Brew: Perfect Summer Drink
cold_brew.subtitle: How to make cold coffee at home
cold_brew.intro: Cold brew is coffee brewed cold for 12-24 hours. The result is a smooth, sweet drink without bitterness.

natural_washed.title: Natural vs Washed Processing
natural_washed.subtitle: How processing method affects taste
natural_washed.intro: Coffee processing is removing pulp from the cherry. Two main methods ‚Äî natural (dry) and washed (wet) ‚Äî create drastically different flavor profiles.

arabica_vs_robusta.title: Arabica vs Robusta: The Full Truth About Two Coffee Types
arabica_vs_robusta.intro: "100% Arabica" ‚Äî you've seen this on every other coffee pack. But what does it really mean? And why does Robusta have such a bad reputation? Let's explore the two main coffee types in detail.

arabica_vs_robusta.p1: "100% Arabica" ‚Äî you've seen this on every other coffee pack. But what does it mean?
arabica_vs_robusta.p2: Arabica is a demanding beauty. It needs special conditions.
arabica_vs_robusta.p3: Arabica is famous for its complex flavor with fruity notes.
arabica_vs_robusta.p4: Robusta is a hardy plant that withstands tougher conditions.
arabica_vs_robusta.p5: Quality Robusta has its place in the coffee world.

bean_to_cup.p3: Critical factors: altitude, shade, soil, care.
bean_to_cup.p5: Cherries are processed using washed or natural methods.

brewing_methods.title: All Coffee Brewing Methods: Complete Guide
brewing_methods.intro: There are countless ways to brew coffee, and each reveals different aspects of flavor. Let's break down all popular methods.
brewing_methods.subtitle: From Turkish pot to Aeropress ‚Äî an overview of all brewing methods.
brewing_methods.p1: The brewing method affects taste just as much as the coffee variety.
brewing_methods.p2: Coffee is immersed in water, and all substances extract.
brewing_methods.p3: Water passes through coffee by gravity.
brewing_methods.p5: Coffee and water are boiled together.

coffee_processing.title: Coffee Processing: From Cherry to Bean

coffee_processing.p1: After harvest, cherries undergo processing ‚Äî one of the most important stages.
coffee_processing.p2: In natural processing, the cherry dries whole.
coffee_processing.p4: Honey processing is the golden mean.
coffee_processing.p5: Each method produces a unique flavor profile.

coffee_seasonality.title: Coffee Seasonality: When to Drink Fresh Coffee
coffee_seasonality.intro: Coffee is a seasonal product, like fruits or vegetables. Each region has its own harvest season.
coffee_seasonality.subtitle: Why coffee is a seasonal product and the best times for different regions.
coffee_seasonality.p1: Coffee is a seasonal product, like grapes or apples.
coffee_seasonality.p2: Ethiopia: November-February. Best fresh coffee from February.
coffee_seasonality.p3: Colombia has two harvests per year.
coffee_seasonality.p5: Fresh coffee is max 4 weeks after roasting.

blog_coffee_storage.intro: Proper storage is key to preserving coffee's taste and aroma.

cold_brew_guide.p1: Cold brew is coffee brewed with cold water.
cold_brew_guide.p4: Can be stored in fridge for up to 2 weeks.
cold_brew_guide.p5: Serve over ice or dilute with water.

about_page.hero_title: From Ethiopian Mountains to Your Cup
about_page.hero_text: We are a team of coffee lovers who built a direct supply chain from Ethiopia
about_page.why_ethiopia_p1: Ethiopia is the birthplace of coffee. Here, at altitudes of 1800-2200 meters, unique Arabica varieties grow that exist nowhere else in the world. Over 10,000 varieties ‚Äî and none of them repeats another.
about_page.why_ethiopia_p2: Each of our lots is a separate story, a separate terroir, a separate flavor profile. From floral Yirgacheffe to berry Guji ‚Äî we offer the full palette of Ethiopian specialty.
